bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Estela Agramonte Rodriguez Leon, November 10, 1947

div1.p: Hench mentions the lack of cooperation by Cuban doctors in memorializing Camp Lazear. He notes that he has been able to obtain research materials from the Reed and Lazear families, but little from the Carroll family, and he is pleased that Rodriguez Leon has assembled her father's papers.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Estela Agramonte Rodriguez Leon, November 10, 1947
div1.opener:
November 10, 1947
Senora Estela Agramonte Rodriguez Leon
Avenida K 254 entre 15 Y 17
Vedado, Habana
Cuba
My dear Senora Rodriguez Leon:
div1.p:
I must offer you my sincere apologies for not having answered
long ago your kind letter of April 8. At that time, and for five months there-
after, I was completely immersed in one of the most difficult jobs I ever
took on; namely, the publication of a review of all the English-speaking
literature on rheumatic diseases for the last five years. I gave up every-
thing. I practically saw nothing of my family, gave up a vacation trip,
neglected to answer my correspondence and at times even forgot to pay my
bills. I have just finished the job and am now “back in circulation” again.

You will be interested to know that we are making slow progress
in the matter of our mutual interest; namely, the real story of the conquest
of yellow fever. This spring I had some correspondence with two Cuban physi-
cians, Doctor Nogueira and Doctor Andreu, who wrote to me telling me about
their plans to join with me in memorializing Camp Lazear. However, I have
been rather discouraged about the cooperation I have received from them.
One of these letters was actually in answer to a letter I had written 18
months before. To their letters I sent a long detailed reply. Although
this was weeks ago. I have had no answer. I have just written them again and have
asked Johnny Moran to try to find out what is wrong. I am even more anxious
to cooperate with them than they think I am but they don't seem to respond to
my efforts. I have heard that at least the government named Camp Lazear a
national monument. But giving the place simply a name without raising funds
and making plans to preserve it seems to be inappropriate. The Mayo Clinic
is still willing to make a generous donation to our proposal and I am hoping
to see an associate of the Rockefeller family in New York in a week or so
to interest him also, so that from this side of the water we still have our
hopes and plans.

I have been asked to speak on November 17, at the Medical
School of the University of Virginia on the conquest of yellow fever. You
will remember that Walter Reed, Moran, and General Kean were all students
at the University of Virginia. In the lecture which I plan to give, I have
two or three nice lantern slides with photographs of your father. These I
certainly plan to show. I have received an even nicer invitation to speak
on the “Walter Reed Memorial Day”, May 12, before the International Congress
on Tropical Medicine, held in Washington. On that day a statue of Walter
Reed will be unveiled and presented to the Hall of Fame.

I have continued to assemble as much material as possible
concerning all the members of the Yellow Fever Commission and I have been
most fortunate in getting great help from the Reed family and the Lazear
Senora Estela Agramonte Rodriguez Leon
- 2 -
November 10, 1947
family, who have given me or loaned me practically everything they have.
What they chose not to add to this collection they allowed me to copy. They
realize that this collection must not belong to any one individual but must
be assembled for proper safeguard and displayed in some large medical insti-
tution. Unfortunately, I have not gotten much from the Carroll Family. Sad
to relate, the son, George Carroll, believes his father was not given due
credit. You know all about that old sad story, but as the result of these
feelings, he has been frankly hostile and I have not been able to make him
understand that I want to give his father full credit if only he would put
in my hands, such documents and papers as he has, which will show more clearly
his father's contribution.

I am indeed delighted to hear that after these many years you
have been able to collect all of your father's papers and bring them to your
present home. I am already preparing the preliminary manuscript for the book
that I hope to publish. I must confess that I do not have nearly enough on
your father. I do need your help badly and I am delighted to know that you
have been able to collect the old material. Because of its extreme importance
to all concerned, I should like to come to Havana and spend a few days there
reviewing your material. Would it be possible for me to do this, perhaps in
March? I can arrange to come over to Cuba from Florida where Mrs. Hench and
I had hoped to take a winter vacation. This is very important to me and I
will promise that I will not be any more of a bother than I can help. I have
made a thorough search of the National Archives, the old War Department records,
the Army Medical Museum and other sources and have found not nearly enough to
satisfy me as to your father's contribution. Of course, I know the general
story, but that isn't what I am after. I'm after details, such as one could
only find in personal letters, diaries, memoranda and notes. As you say, “the
Finlay fever” is raging in Cuba. I shall be delighted indeed to have you
translate my book into Spanish.

Please allow me to send the congratulations of Mrs. Hench and
me on the birth of a little baby girl. Aren't they wonderful? Our four
children are getting quite grown up. The oldest girl, age 18, is a freshman
at a college in Vermont. The oldest boy, 17 years old, is in a prep school
in Pennsylvania. The 14-year old girl is home but will go to a girls' school
in Ohio next year and our little 4 1/2 year old boy is a great joy but he cer-
tainly is active.

If I were able to come to visit you in March, I would try to
disturb you as little as possible. I could review the material in your home
at hours convenient to you, making notes and perhaps making arrangements to
photostat or photograph the more important items. If necessary I can obtain
the services of a stenographer. In the hope that I might be able to make this
visit, I shall write to the Hotel Nacional to see if they can make reservations
for me. It would indeed be a distinct pleasure to come.

I wonder if I have sent you a photograph of the mural honoring
your father on the wall of the Agramonte Memorial Library at the Medical Center,
Louisiana State University. It is a bronze mural and I believe I had sent you
one but if not, let me know and I will send you one with much pleasure. I do
hope that a review of your data will give me an even clearer picture of your
father's distinguished contribution.

It will be most appropriate for me to have this material
at the time of the International Congress in May and Doctor Sawyer, the
chairman of the program committee, has asked me to see to it that although
my talk (it has been called the “principal oration”) is to be given on the
Walter Reed Memorial Day, I am to give full credit to all concerned, in-
cluding Finlay, of course. By the way, I would certainly like to see the
items you mentioned, the papers of the Noguchi controversy and also the
original print of Beaperthuy's article. I have never been able to get a
copy of the latter.
div1.closer: Sincerely, Philip S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alc
